TEXT.English: [TAB]Baghatur is an old Altaic term for a warrior, a military commander, or an epic hero. The word was introduced in the Middle Ages to many non-Altaic languages by conquering Turkic- and Mongol-speaking nomads, and now exists in different forms such as the Russian Bogatyr', Polish Bohater (meaning hero), Persian and North Indian Bahadur, and Georgian Bagatur. It is also preserved in the modern Turkic and Mongol languages as Turkish Batur, Tatar and Kazakh Batyr, Uzbek Batyr and Mongolian Baatar (as in Ulaanbaatar).

It is also preserved in the modern Turkic and Mongol languages as Turkish Batur, Tatar and Kazakh Batyr, Uzbek Batyr and Mongolian Baatar (as in Ulaanbaatar).

TEXT.English: The Kazakh replacement for the Knight can move on terrain without penalty.
TEXT.French: Le remplacement kazakh du chevalier peut se déplacer sur un terrain sans pénalité.
TEXT.German: The Kazakh replacement for the Knight can move on terrain without penalty.
TEXT.Italian: The Kazakh replacement for the Knight can move on terrain without penalty.
TEXT.Spanish: The Kazakh replacement for the Knight can move on terrain without penalty.
